experimentDesign.title: Tether Blind Comparison Study
experimentDesign.hypothesis: Clinicians will prefer psychometrically-matched resource recommendations over logistics-matched recommendations when both are presented with identical formatting.
experimentDesign.primaryMetric: % of comparisons where participant selects the psychometrically-matched plan
experimentDesign.secondaryMetric: Qualitative themes in reasoning (do participants spontaneously cite psychometric factors?)
experimentDesign.presentation: Both plans show identical fields: resource name, tier, description, schedule, location/distance, cost, intake. No match rationale on either. Labels are 'Plan 1' and 'Plan 2' with randomized assignment.
experimentDesign.successThreshold: 70% preference for Version A across all cases

cases.presentingProblem: Second depressive episode triggered by social isolation after relocating to Roanoke 2 years ago. Stabilized on sertraline 100mg over the past 6 weeks.
cases.currentTreatment: Sertraline 100mg daily. Adherent to medication and appointments.
relevantHistory: Lives alone, limited local social network
Moved for a relationship that ended
cases.functionalStatus: Remote customer service rep (Mon-Fri 9-5). Low energy in evenings, mornings are better. Rarely leaves apartment outside of work and groceries.
patientReported: Finds most social suggestions overwhelming
Tried a support group once, described it as 'depressing'
Used to enjoy hiking and outdoors before the move
Prefers side-by-side activities over face-to-face conversation
Open to short-term commitments, not ongoing obligations
cases.clinicalGoal: Increase social engagement and community connection to support recovery.
cases.viewerContext: You are reviewing this as the treating psychiatrist.

versionA.hidden_logic: Selected based on morning energy pattern, preference for side-by-side activities, past hiking interest, aversion to traditional support group format, preference for short-term/drop-in commitment

recommendations.description: Weekly beginner group hikes, casual pace. Members range from 20s to 60s.

recommendations.description: Structured behavioral activation and thought patterns group. Licensed psychologist. 6-8 participants.

recommendations.name: NAMI Peer-to-Peer Course
recommendations.description: Free 8-session mental health recovery education taught by trained peers with lived experience.

versionB.hidden_logic: Selected based on proximity, diagnosis category, insurance eligibility, and general availability

recommendations.description: Peer-led support group for depression/bipolar. Open discussion format, circle setting.

recommendations.description: Process-oriented group therapy for mood disorders. Licensed clinical social worker. Ongoing enrollment.

recommendations.name: Roanoke Parks & Rec - Adult Fitness Programs
recommendations.description: Group fitness classes: yoga, aerobics, strength training. Multiple city recreation centers.

cases.presentingProblem: Chronic worry and physical tension escalating over the past year. Avoids social situations where she might be put on the spot. GI complaints and insomnia.
cases.currentTreatment: Escitalopram 10mg for 3 months, seeing improvement. Biweekly CBT.
relevantHistory: Lives with partner, moved from larger city 18 months ago for partner's job
Left behind a close-knit friend group
cases.functionalStatus: Graphic designer, mostly remote. Avoids crowded or unpredictable settings. Tolerates small structured groups (3-5 people). Evenings are worst for anxiety.
patientReported: Enjoys drawing and ceramics but hasn't pursued them locally
Tried a large yoga class once, left early due to crowds
Needs to know what to expect before showing up somewhere new
Comfortable one-on-one or groups of 3-5
Mornings and early afternoons are best
cases.clinicalGoal: Gradual social re-engagement with structured, low-pressure activities that build tolerance without triggering avoidance.

clinicianSettings.contraindications: Avoid large-group or performance-based settings initially

cases.viewerContext: You are reviewing this as the treating psychiatrist.

versionA.hidden_logic: Selected based on preference for small/structured groups, creative interests, need for predictability, morning/early afternoon energy, avoidance of crowded/unpredictable settings

cases.presentingProblem: Diagnosed at 19 after academic struggles. Medication helps focus in class but social life and daily structure remain chaotic. Frequently forgets commitments or signs up and never follows through.
cases.currentTreatment: Adderall XR 20mg daily, mornings. Monthly psychiatrist visits. No therapy.
relevantHistory: Socially active but relationships stay surface-level
cases.functionalStatus: Virginia Tech senior, IT major. Part-time campus IT help desk (15 hrs/wk). Functions well medicated (8am-4pm). Evenings unstructured, hyperfocuses on gaming late at night.
patientReported: Loves hands-on activities, building and fixing things
Played intramural basketball but stopped because he kept forgetting game times
Gets bored quickly with anything repetitive or lecture-based
Prefers immediate feedback over long-term goals
Hates paperwork and 'administrative overhead'
cases.clinicalGoal: Build structured routines outside of academics and find social outlets that accommodate ADHD-related challenges with follow-through and time management.
cases.viewerContext: You are reviewing this as the treating psychiatrist.

versionA.hidden_logic: Selected based on preference for hands-on/novel activities, need for low administrative overhead, medication window (mornings best), history of drop-off with scheduling demands, preference for immediate engagement over long-term commitment

cases.presentingProblem: Escalating drinking over 3 years post-divorce. Completed outpatient detox 60 days ago. Currently sober but struggling with evenings and weekends.
cases.currentTreatment: Naltrexone 50mg daily. Completed IOP 4 weeks ago. Psychiatrist biweekly, therapy weekly.
relevantHistory: Divorced, shares custody of two kids (8 and 11) every other weekend
Lives alone in a rented townhouse
Drinking was solitary, at home, evenings
cases.functionalStatus: Electrician (Mon-Fri 7am-3:30pm), performing well at work. Evenings are high-risk. One close friend from work who drinks socially. Weekends without kids feel empty. Physically active.
patientReported: AA felt 'too religious,' but open to meeting others in recovery
Misses team sports camaraderie
Wants structured evening/weekend activities
Uncomfortable talking about feelings in groups, prefers natural conversation during activities
Needs alcohol-free environments
cases.clinicalGoal: Build a sober social network and structured evening/weekend activities to reduce relapse risk during high-vulnerability windows.

clinicianSettings.contraindications: No environments where alcohol is served or present

cases.viewerContext: You are reviewing this as the treating psychiatrist.

versionA.hidden_logic: Selected based on evening/weekend scheduling priority, preference for activity-based over talk-based, team sports background, resistance to spiritual framing, need for alcohol-free environments, preference for peer camaraderie

cases.presentingProblem: Diagnosed at 13 after academic difficulties. Medication helps at school but afternoons and weekends are unstructured. Spends most free time alone on screens. Parents concerned about social isolation.
cases.currentTreatment: Concerta 36mg daily before school. Psychiatrist every 2 months. No therapy. Parents involved.
relevantHistory: Lives with both parents and sister (12)
Small friend group from middle school dispersed across different high schools
cases.functionalStatus: High school sophomore, B/C grades with medication. Medication effective 7am-3pm. Afternoons unmedicated and unstructured, 4-6 hours daily on YouTube and gaming. Socially passive but participates if someone else organizes.
patientReported: Likes building things: Legos, Minecraft
Interested in computers/coding but hasn't tried classes
Quit soccer because practices felt too long and repetitive
Prefers hands-on over sitting and listening
Doesn't want anything that feels 'like more school'
cases.clinicalGoal: Develop structured after-school and weekend activities that build social connections and executive function skills in a low-pressure environment.
cases.viewerContext: You are reviewing this as Ethan's parent. Your psychiatrist generated these recommendations after Ethan's last appointment.

versionA.hidden_logic: Selected based on building/hands-on interests, coding curiosity, aversion to lecture/repetitive formats, preference for short-burst engagement, afternoon timing (post-medication), low social pressure entry point

cases.presentingProblem: Diagnosed at 11. Academically strong but increasingly socially isolated in high school. Rigid routines, difficulty with unstructured social time. Meltdowns increasing since starting 9th grade from sensory overload and unexpected schedule changes.
cases.currentTreatment: No medication. Biweekly psychologist for social skills and emotional regulation. Parents are primary support.
relevantHistory: Lives with both parents and older brother (17)
One close friend from middle school moved away last summer
No behavioral concerns at school, described as 'very quiet'
cases.functionalStatus: Honors freshman, high-performing academically but socially exhausted by end of school day. Needs 1-2 hours alone to decompress. Sensitive to loud noise, fluorescent lighting, crowds. Communicates well one-on-one but shuts down in groups over 4-5. Eats lunch alone in the library.
patientReported: Passionate about marine biology, can talk about it extensively
Enjoys detailed scientific illustrations of sea creatures
Finds most teen activities 'too loud and confusing'
Wants friends but doesn't know how to start conversations outside her interests
Needs to know exactly what will happen before going, including who will be there
cases.clinicalGoal: Build social connections through interest-based activities in sensory-appropriate, predictable environments with small group sizes.

clinicianSettings.contraindications: Avoid loud, crowded, or unpredictable environments. Avoid activities requiring significant unscripted social interaction.

cases.viewerContext: You are reviewing this as Lily's parent. Your psychiatrist generated these recommendations after Lily's last appointment.

versionA.hidden_logic: Selected based on marine biology special interest, drawing interest, sensory needs (quiet/low-stimulation), small group size requirement, need for predictability and advance information, preference for parallel or interest-based interaction over unstructured socializing
